DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Carcinoid Tumor Primary Location Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the category to indicate a class of named locations or anatomic sites of, or within, the body relating to a carcinoid tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Carcinoid Tumor Primary Location
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the primary location of a slow growing neuroendocrine tumor, composed of uniform, round, or polygonal cells having monotonous, centrally located nuclei and small nucleoli, infrequent mitoses, and no necrosis and often involving the gastrointestinal tract and lung.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: A slow growing neuroendocrine tumor, composed of uniform, round, or polygonal cells having monotonous, centrally located nuclei and small nucleoli, infrequent mitoses, and no necrosis. The tumor may show a variety of patterns, such as solid, trabecular, and acinar. Electron microscopy shows small secretory granules. Immunohistochemical studies reveal NSE, as well as chromogranin immunoreactivity. Malignant histology (cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, necrosis, and mitoses) can occasionally be seen. Such cases may have an aggressive clinical course. Gastrointestinal tract and lung are common sites of involvement.:Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.:A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

Concepts.definition: A slow growing neuroendocrine tumor, composed of uniform, round, or polygonal cells having monotonous, centrally located nuclei and small nucleoli, infrequent mitoses, and no necrosis.  The tumor may show a variety of patterns, such as solid, trabecular, and acinar.  Electron microscopy shows small secretory granules.  Immunohistochemical studies reveal NSE, as well as chromogranin immunoreactivity.  Malignant histology (cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, necrosis, and mitoses) can occasionally be seen.  Such cases may have an aggressive clinical course.  Gastrointestinal tract and lung are common sites of involvement.
Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Carcinoid Tumor Primary Malignant Neoplasm Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the category to indicate a class of named locations or anatomic sites of, or within, the body relating to a carcinoid tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: The middle region (foregut, midgut and hindgut) of the early formation of the digestive tract in the developing embryo, which gives rise to the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, and colon from the cecum to the distal transverse colon.: Pertaining to the stomach and intestines.: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.

The middle region (foregut, midgut and hindgut) of the early formation of the digestive tract in the developing embryo, which gives rise to the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, and colon from the cecum to the distal transverse colon.
Pertaining to the stomach and intestines.

One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Midgut Duodenum Jejunum Ileum Appendix Cecum Unknown

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Midgut Duodenum Jejunum Ileum Appendix Cecum Unknown
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The middle region (foregut, midgut and hindgut) of the early formation of the digestive tract in the developing embryo, which gives rise to the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, and colon from the cecum to the distal transverse colon.: A jointed tube 25-30 cm long that connects the stomach to the jejunum.: The portion of the small intestine that extends from the duodenum to the ileum.: The final section of the small intestine.: Small tissue projection existing as a cecal diverticulum with a questionable history of vestigial versus specialized organ.: A blind pouch-like commencement of the colon in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen at the end of the small intestine and the start of the large intestine.: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: The middle region (foregut, midgut and hindgut) of the early formation of the digestive tract in the developing embryo, which gives rise to the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, and colon from the cecum to the distal transverse colon.
A jointed tube 25-30 cm long that connects the stomach to the jejunum.
The portion of the small intestine that extends from the duodenum to the ileum.
The final section of the small intestine.
Small tissue projection existing as a cecal diverticulum with a questionable history of vestigial versus specialized organ.
A blind pouch-like commencement of the colon in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen at the end of the small intestine and the start of the large intestine.
Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Negation Midgut Gastrointestinal Stomach Negation Cecum Rectum Lung Other

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Negation Midgut Gastrointestinal Stomach Negation Cecum Rectum Lung Other
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: The middle region (foregut, midgut and hindgut) of the early formation of the digestive tract in the developing embryo, which gives rise to the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, and colon from the cecum to the distal transverse colon.: Pertaining to the stomach and intestines.: An organ located under the diaphragm, between the liver and the spleen as well as between the esophagus and the small intestine. The stomach is the primary organ of food digestion.: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: A blind pouch-like commencement of the colon in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen at the end of the small intestine and the start of the large intestine.: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.

The middle region (foregut, midgut and hindgut) of the early formation of the digestive tract in the developing embryo, which gives rise to the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, and colon from the cecum to the distal transverse colon.
Pertaining to the stomach and intestines.
The primary organ of food digestion. It is located under the diaphragm, between the liver and the spleen as well as between the esophagus and the small intestine.
An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
A blind pouch-like commencement of the colon in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen at the end of the small intestine and the start of the large intestine.
The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
